I like projects that touch reality. Not just ‚Äúit compiles‚Äù, but things that run on real devices, real networks, and real users.

That means I spend a lot of time doing two jobs: building and operating. I‚Äôll ship a feature in a Flutter app, then later I‚Äôm troubleshooting a network issue, updating a POS workflow, or deploying a clean Windows image to a caf√© PC.

Shipping is only half the work

When you deploy software, the world fights back: bad cables, misconfigured DNS, weird Windows updates, old hardware, and humans clicking everything.

That‚Äôs not a complaint ‚Äî that‚Äôs the fun part. You learn fast when you own the full loop.

My favorite kind of work: build it, run it, maintain it, improve it.

The mindset I try to keep

When something breaks, I try to do two things:

  1. Fix it quickly (so people can continue using it)
  2. Fix it properly (so it doesn‚Äôt break the same way again)

That usually means writing notes, adding a tiny script, or improving monitoring so the next incident is easier.

Sometimes the best ‚Äúfeature‚Äù is boring:

  • A better backup routine
  • A clearer log message
  • A simple health check
  • A safer deploy process

Closing
